sen.j: 楠木 正成（くすのき まさしげ）は、鎌倉時代末期から南北朝時代 (日本)にかけての河内の武将。
sen.e: Masashige KUSUNOKI was a busho (Japanese military commander) who lived in Kawachi Province from the end of the Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).
Masashige KUSUNOKI was a busho (Japanese military commander) who lived in Kawachi Province from the end of the Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府からは（悪党）とよばれた。
sen.e: He was called "Akuto" (rebel) by Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
He was called "Akuto" (rebel) by Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
He was called "rebel" by the Kamakura Shogunate.

sen.j: 建武の新政の立役者として足利尊氏らと共に活躍。
sen.e: He participated actively as a leading figure in the Kenmu Restoration with Takauji ASHIKAGA and others.
He participated actively as a leading figure in the Kenmu Restoration with Takauji ASHIKAGA and others.
He participated actively as a leading figure in the Kenmu Restoration with Takauji ASHIKAGA and others.

sen.j: 恩賞方・武者所・記録所寄人・雑訴決断所奉行、和泉守護。
sen.e: He served not only as yoriudo (a dependent, frequently one who served a noble house or proprietor) at Onshokata (office to do desk works of Onsho award), Mushadokoro (place where Samurai of guard of the Imperial Palace is staffed) and Kirokujo (Land Record Office), but also as Zasso-Ketsudansho bugyo (magistrate of agency of Kenmu Government to file lawsuits) and Izumi Shugo (military governor of Izumi).
sen.cmt: 恩賞方・武者所・記録所寄人: 「恩賞方」「武者所」「記録所」は執務場所を示すため、「恩賞方、武者所および記録所で寄人(を務めた)」 と解釈されますので、その意味で訳しております。
sen.e: He served not only as yoriudo (a dependent, frequently one who served a noble house or proprietor) at Onshokata (office to do desk works of Onsho award), Mushadokoro (place where Samurai of guard of the Imperial Palace is staffed) and Kirokujo (Land Record Office), but also as Zasso-Ketsudansho bugyo (magistrate of agency of Kenmu Government to file lawsuits) and Izumi Shugo (military governor of Izumi).

He served not only as a clerk at the office of Rewards, the warriors' office, and the land record office, but also as the magistrate of agency of Kenmu Government to file lawsuits and the military governor of Izumi.

sen.j: 贈正一位（1880年）。
sen.e: Zo shoichii (Senior First Rank, posthumously conferred) (1880).

sen.e: Zo shoichii (Senior First Rank, posthumously conferred) (1880).

sen.j: 尊氏反抗後新政の軍事主体の主力の一方になり、最後まで勤王をつらぬく。
sen.e: After the betrayal of Takauji, Masashige played a major role in the military of the Restoration and gave his loyalty to the Emperor till the last.

sen.j: 足利尊氏の軍と戦い湊川で自害。
sen.e: He fought against the army of Takauji ASHIKAGA and committed suicide in Minatogawa.

sen.j: 明治以降「大楠公」と称される。
sen.e: He has been called "Dai-Nanko" (the Elder Lord of Kusunoki) since the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: 大楠公: 用語登録では「Dai-Nanko」のみの表記ですが、Translator Guidelinesの指示により、説明が必要なため、カッコ内に説明を加えております(ただしこれは定訳ではありません)

sen.j: 父は系図により楠木正遠あるいは正玄、正澄、正康、俊親などと伝え、はっきりしていない。
sen.e: As his father is supposed to have been Masatoo, Masaharu, Masazumi, Masayasu or Toshichika KUSUNOKI, depending on various genealogical charts, it is not certain who his father was.
sen.cmt: 正康: 用語登録では「Seiko(読み方不明)」とされていますが、楠木家で名前に「正」が付く人物の名前は「まさ…」と読むため、「まさやす」のほうが確率が高いと思われますので、こちらを採用しております / 俊親: 読み方が確認できませんので、最も一般的と思われる読み方を当てております(用語登録でも「Toshichika(読み方不明)」とされています。
sen.e: As his father is supposed to have been Masatoo, Masaharu, Masazumi, Masayasu or Toshichika KUSUNOKI, depending on various genealogical charts, it is not certain who his father was.

sen.j: 楠木氏は、伊予国の伊予橘氏（越智氏）の橘遠保の末裔という。
sen.e: The Kusunoki clan is said to be descendants of TACHIBANA no Toyasu of the Iyotachibana clan (Ochi clan) in Iyo Province.
The Kusunoki clan is said to be descended from TACHIBANA no Toyasu of the Iyotachibana clan (Ochi clan) in Iyo Province.

sen.j: しかし、正成以前の系図は諸家で一致せず、後世の創作と見られる。
sen.e: But a genealogical chart before Masashige of one family of the clan varies from those of the other families, so the charts were likely created by later generations.
But a genealogical chart before Masashige of one family of the clan varies from those of the other families, so the charts were likely created by later generations.

sen.j: 河内国には楠木姓の由来となるような地名はなく、北条氏得宗家被官の一族で、得宗領の河内へ移ってきたとする説、武蔵国（関東地方）の出身であるとする説などがある。
sen.e: Because there is no geographical name deriving from the family name "Kusunoki" in Kawachi Province, some insist that the clan had served as low-level bureaucrat of the Tokuso Family of the Hojo clan and moved later to Kawachi, which was a territory of the Tokuso family of the Hojo clan, but others have different opinions such as one that the clan originally comes from Musashi Province (Kanto region).

Because there is no geographical name derived from the family name "Kusunoki" in Kawachi Province, some insist that the clan served as low-level bureaucrat of the Tokuso Family of the Hojo clan and moved later to Kawachi, which was a territory of the Tokuso family of the Hojo clan, but others have different opinions such as one that the clan originally comes from Musashi Province (Kanto region).

Because there is no geographical name derived from the family name "Kusunoki" in Kawachi Province, some insist that the clan served as low-level official of the Tokuso family of the Hojo clan and moved later to Kawachi (a territory of the Tokuso family of the Hojo clan), but others have different opinions, including one that states that that the clan originally came from Musashi Province (Kanto region).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 河内国石川郡赤坂村（現大阪府南河内郡千早赤阪村）の出生とする。
sen.e: It is believed that he was born in Akasaka Village, Ishikawa District, Kawachi Province (present-day Chihaya-Akasaka-mura, Minamikawachi-gun, Osaka Prefecture).

sen.j: 生年に関しての確実な史料は存在せず、正成の前半生はほとんど不明で、日本史上きわめて有名でありながら出自がこれほど謎に包まれた人物はほかにいないといわれる。
sen.e: Because there is no historical material proving his birth date and the first half of his life is almost unknown, it is said that there is no one else whose origin is so mysterious as that of Masashige, although he is highly famous in Japanese history.

Because there is no historical material proving his birth date and the first half of his life is almost unknown, it is said that there is no one else whose origin is so mysterious as that of Masashige, although he is highly famous in Japanese history.

Because there is no historical material proving his birth date and the first half of his life is mostly unknown, there is no one else whose origin is so mysterious as that of Masashige, although he is highly well-known in Japanese history.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 様々な歴史家による懸命な研究努力にも拘らず、正成が確かな実像として捉えられるのは、元弘元年の挙兵から建武3年の湊川での自刃までのわずか6年ほどに過ぎない。
sen.e: Despite exhausting efforts by several historians, a real image of Masashige can be drawn only for the time of six years from raising an army in 1331 to committing suicide in Minatogawa in 1336.
Despite exhaustive efforts by several historians, a real image of Masashige could only be drawn during a period of six years from raising an army in 1331 to committing suicide in Minatogawa in 1336.
Despite exhaustive efforts by several historians, a true picture of Masashige could only be seen in a period of six years from raising an army in 1331 to committing suicide in Minatogawa in 1336.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 元弘元年（1331年）臨川寺領和若松荘「悪党楠木兵衛尉」として史料に名を残しており、鎌倉幕府の御家人帳にない河内を中心に付近一帯の水銀などの流通ルートで活動する「悪党」とよばれる豪族であったと考えられている。
sen.e: Because his name was recorded in a historical material in 1331 as "Hyoenojo KUSUNOKI of Akuto"at wa-wakamatsu-sho in the territory of Rinsen-ji Temple, he is considered to have been a member of a powerful clan that was called "Akuto" and worked in distribution of quicksilver and others in the area around Kawachi, which was not registered in Gokenin cho (register of lower-ranking vassal in the Kamakura and Edo periods) by Kamakura bakufu.
sen.cmt: 和若松荘: 「天竜寺文書」という史料には「和泉国若松荘」と記載されているため(http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=B-pBRw52qKAC&pg=PA99&lpg=PA99&dq=%22%E5%A4%A9%E7%AB%9C%E5%AF%BA%E6%96%87%E6%9B%B8%22+%22%E8%8B%A5%E6%9D%BE%22&source=bl&ots=jv1l5ODEXR&sig=VZ5ow7vxS3JiQb11nXc0mB-xhr8&hl=ja&ei=Kv7eStT-GoaUkAXl2fkX&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CAwQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22%E5%A4%A9%E7%AB%9C%E5%AF%BA%E6%96%87%E6%9B%B8%22%20%22%E8%8B%A5%E6%9D%BE%22&f=false)、正しくは「和泉国若松荘」または「和泉若松荘(いずみわかまつしょう)」と推測されますが、Webでも「和若松荘」となっているため、原文通りに「わ・わかまつしょう」と記載しております。用語登録とは異なり、「臨川寺領」はローマ字表記ではなく、「臨川寺の領」と訳しております。
sen.e: Because his name was recorded in a historical material in 1331 as "Hyoenojo KUSUNOKI of Akuto"at wa-wakamatsu-sho in the territory of Rinsen-ji Temple, he is considered to have been a member of a powerful clan that was called "Akuto" and worked in distribution of quicksilver and others in the area around Kawachi, which was not registered in Gokenin cho (register of lower-ranking vassal in the Kamakura and Edo periods) by Kamakura bakufu.

Because his name was recorded in historical materials in 1331 as 'Hyoenojo KUSUNOKI of Akuto' at wa-wakamatsu-sho in the territory of Rinsen-ji Temple, he is considered to have been a member of a powerful clan that was called 'Akuto' and worked in distribution of quicksilver and others in the area around Kawachi, which was not registered in the record of lower-ranking vassal of the Kamakura shogunate 'Gokenin cho' by Kamakura shogunate.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また、この時既に官職を帯びていることから、これ以前に朝廷に仕え、後醍醐天皇もしくはその周囲の人物達と接触を持っていたと思われる。
sen.e: Since he already had a government post at that time, it is believed that he had served the Imperial Court and had kept contact with Emperor Godaigo or his acquaintances before.

sen.j: この年に後醍醐天皇の挙兵を聞くと下赤坂城にて挙兵し、湯浅定仏と戦う（赤坂城の戦い）。
sen.e: As he heard of raising an army of Emperor Godaigo that year, he also raised an army at Shimoakasaka-jo Castle to fight against Jobutsu YUASA (Battle of Akasaka-jo Castle).
As he heard of raising an army of Emperor Godaigo that year, he also raised an army at Shimoakasaka-jo Castle to fight against Jobutsu YUASA (Battle of Akasaka-jo Castle).

sen.j: 後醍醐と正成を結びつけたのは、伊賀兼光、あるいは真言宗の僧である文観と思われる。
sen.e: It is believed that the person who introduced Masashige to Emperor Godaigo was Kanemitsu IGA or Monkan, a monk of the Shingon Sect.
It is believed that the person who introduced Masashige to Emperor Godaigo was Kanemitsu IGA or Monkan, a monk of the Shingon Sect.
It is believed that the person who introduced Masashige to Emperor Godaigo was Kanemitsu IGA or Monkan, a monk of the Shingon Sect.

sen.j: 後醍醐が隠岐島に流罪となっている間にも、大和国（奈良県）の吉野などで戦った護良親王とともに、河内国の上赤坂城や金剛山 (金剛山地)中腹に築いた山城、千早城に籠城してゲリラ戦法や糞尿攻撃などを駆使して幕府の大軍を相手に奮戦する。
sen.e: While Emperor Godaigo was exiled to Oki no shima Island, Masashige and Imperial Prince Morinaga, who fought with him in Yoshino in Yamato Province (present-day Nara Prefecture) and other places, held Kamiakasaka-jo Castle in Kawachi Province and Chihaya-jo Castle, which was a yamajiro (a castle built on a mountain to take advantage of the mountain's topography) built in the middle of Mt. Kongo (Kongo mountainous district), using guerrilla tactics, excrement attack and others, to fight against a huge army of the bakufu.
sen.cmt: 護良親王: 「もりよし」と読む場合もあります。

Kongo (Kongo mountainous district), using guerrilla tactics, excrement attack and others, to fight against a huge army of the bakufu.

While Emperor Godaigo was exiled to Okinoshima Island, Masashige and Imperial Prince Morinaga, who fought with him in Yoshino in Yamato Province (present-day Nara Prefecture) and other places, held Kamiakasaka-jo Castle in Kawachi Province and Chihaya-jo Castle, which was a a castle built on a mountain to take advantage of the mountain's topography, built in the middle of Mt. Kongo (Kongo mountainous district), using guerrilla tactics, excrement attack and others, to fight against a huge army of the bakufu.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 元弘3年 / 正慶2年（1333年）、正成らの活躍に触発されて各地に倒幕の機運が広がり、足利尊氏や新田義貞、赤松円心らが挙兵して鎌倉幕府は滅びた（元弘の乱）。
sen.e: As the success of Masashige and others increased opportunities to overthrow the Shogunate in various regions in 1333, Takauji ASHIKAGA, Yoshisada NITTA, Enshin AKAMATSU and others raised an army to defeat the Kamakura bakufu (Genko War).

As the success of Masashige and others increased opportunities to overthrow the Shogunate in various regions in 1333, Takauji ASHIKAGA, Yoshisada NITTA, Enshin AKAMATSU and others raised an army to defeat the Kamakura bakufu (Genko War).

As the success of Masashige and others increased opportunities to overthrow the Shogunate in various regions in 1333, warriors including Takauji ASHIKAGA, Yoshisada NITTA, and Enshin AKAMATSU raised an army to defeat the Kamakura bakufu (Genko War).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 後醍醐天皇が京へ凱旋する際、兵庫まで出迎え、同道警護についた。
sen.e: When Emperor Godaigo returned in triumph to Kyoto, Masashige greeted him in Hyogo to accompany him as a bodyguard.
When Emperor Godaigo returned in triumph to Kyoto, Masashige greeted him in Hyogo to accompany him as a bodyguard.
When Emperor Godaigo returned in triumph to Kyoto, Masashige greeted him in Hyogo to accompany him as a bodyguard.

sen.j: 後醍醐天皇の建武の新政が始まると、正成は記録所寄人、雑訴決断所奉行人、河内・和泉国の守護となる。
sen.e: When the Kenmu Restoration started, Masashige served not only as yoriudo at Kirokujo, but also as Zasso-Ketsudansho bugyonin (secretaries of agency of Kenmu Government to file lawsuits) and Shugo of Kawachi and Izumi Provinces.
sen.cmt: 記録所寄人: 既出箇所(9列目)の訳に合わせておりますので、用語登録の訳語とは異なります。
sen.e: When the Kenmu Restoration started, Masashige served not only as yoriudo at Kirokujo, but also as Zasso-Ketsudansho bugyonin (secretaries of agency of Kenmu Government to file lawsuits) and Shugo of Kawachi and Izumi Provinces.
When Emperor Godaigo's Kenmu Restoration started, Masashige served not only as yoriudo at Kirokujo, but also as secretary at Zasso-Ketsudansho and Shugo of Kawachi and Izumi Provinces.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 建武の新政においては正成は後醍醐天皇の絶大な信任を受け、結城親光、名和長年、千種忠顕をあわせて「三木一草」と併称され、「朝恩に誇った」とされる（太平記の記述）。
sen.e: Since Masashige won the deep confidence of Emperor Godaigo in the Kenmu Restoration, it is said that the group of Masashige, Chikamitsu YUKI, Nagatoshi NAWA and Tadaaki CHIGUSA was called "Sanboku-Isso" (literally, "three trees and one grass", because their names or nominal designations have to do with tree or grass), which refers to four meritorious retainers of the Southern Court, so they were "proud of imperial blessing" (this is a description from "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace)).
sen.cmt: 三木一草: Guidelinesの指示により、カッコ内に説明を加えていますが、これは定訳ではありません。尚、「三木一草」として登録されている用語では「Tadaki CHIGUSA」となっていますが、正しくは「ちぐさただあき」ですので、本文では「Tadaaki」と修正しています。
sen.e: Since Masashige won the deep confidence of Emperor Godaigo in the Kenmu Restoration, it is said that the group of Masashige, Chikamitsu YUKI, Nagatoshi NAWA and Tadaaki CHIGUSA was called "Sanboku-Isso" (literally, "three trees and one grass", because their names or nominal designations have to do with tree or grass), which refers to four meritorious retainers of the Southern Court, so they were "proud of imperial blessing" (this is a description from "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace)).

Since Masashige won the deep confidence of Emperor Godaigo in the Kenmu Restoration and the group of Chikamitsu YUKI, Nagatoshi NAWA and Tadaaki CHIGUSA were called 'Sanboku-Isso', it is said that they were 'proud of imperial blessing' (a description from The Record of the Great Peace "Taiheiki").
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 建武 (日本)元年（1334年）冬、正成が北条氏残党を討つために京を離れた直後、護良親王が謀反の嫌疑で捕縛され、足利尊氏に引き渡された。
sen.e: Soon after Masashige had left Kyoto in winter 1334 to defeat the remnants of the Hojo clan, Imperial Prince Morinaga was captured on suspicion of rebellion to be turned over to Takauji ASHIKAGA.
Soon after Masashige had left Kyoto in winter 1334 to defeat the remnants of the Hojo clan, Imperial Prince Morinaga was captured on suspicion of rebellion to be turned over to Takauji ASHIKAGA.
Soon after Masashige had left Kyoto in winter 1334 to defeat the remnants of the Hojo clan, Imperial Prince Morinaga was captured on suspicion of rebellion to be turned over to Takauji ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: その直後、正成は建武政権の役職の多くを辞職したと見られることから、正成は護良親王の有力与力であったと見られている。
sen.e: Because Masashige likely gave up several posts of the Kenmu Government shortly after the capture of Imperial Prince Morinaga, he is considered to have been an important yoriki (literally, "strength that is offered") (a samurai who served warrior-commanders of higher rank) of the Imperial Prince.
sen.cmt: 与力: ここでは、登録されている「a police sergeant」ではなく、参考サイト(http://books.google.com/books?id=DY0XiflmVIAC&pg=PA89&lpg=PA89&dq=imperial+ranks+japan+court&source=bl&ots=87K36orH2v&sig=IFNDpfnIj9qMbfIhYp8s8jhE_JI&hl=en&ei=r7_nSoibCNeIkQWK57jMBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CA0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22yoriki%22&f=false)の177P、178P等に記されている意味で用いられていると思われるため、その説明を引用しました。
sen.e: Because Masashige likely gave up several posts of the Kenmu Government shortly after the capture of Imperial Prince Morinaga, he is considered to have been an important yoriki (literally, "strength that is offered") (a samurai who served warrior-commanders of higher rank) of the Imperial Prince.

Because Masashige likely gave up several posts of the Kenmu Government shortly after the capture of Imperial Prince Morinaga, he is considered to have been an important samurai who served warrior-commanders of higher rank 'yoriki' of the Imperial Prince
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 建武2年（1335年）の中先代の乱を討伐に向かった尊氏がそのまま新政に離反し、尊氏追討の命を受けた義貞が箱根・竹ノ下の戦いに敗北して足利軍が京へ迫るが、北畠顕家らと連絡して足利方を京より駆逐する。
sen.e: As Takauji went to put down the Nakasendai War in 1335, did not come back and seceded from the Kenmu Government, Yoshisada was ordered to hunt down and kill him, which resulted in the defeat of Yoshisada in the Battle of Hakone Take no Shita, so the Ashikaga side approached to Kyoto, but Masashige contacted Akiie KITABATAKE and others to expel the Ashikaga side from Kyoto.

As Takauji went to put down the Nakasendai War in 1335, did not come back and seceded from the Kenmu Government, Yoshisada was ordered to hunt down and kill him, which resulted in the defeat of Yoshisada in the Battle of Hakone Take no Shita, so the Ashikaga side approached to Kyoto, but Masashige contacted Akiie KITABATAKE and others to expel the Ashikaga side from Kyoto.

As Takauji went to win the Nakasendai War in 1335 and seceded from the Kenmu Government, Yoshisada was ordered to track down and kill Takauji, which resulted in the defeat of Yoshisada in the Battle of Hakone Take no Shita, so the Ashikaga side approached to Kyoto, but Masashige contacted Akiie KITABATAKE and others to expel the Ashikaga side from Kyoto.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 延元元年 / 建武3年（1336年）、足利方が九州で軍勢を整えて再び京都へ迫ると、正成は後醍醐天皇に新田義貞を切り捨てて尊氏と和睦するよう進言するが容認されず、次善の策として、一旦天皇の京都からの撤退を進言するがこれも却下される。
sen.e: When the Ashikaga's troops established themselves in Kyushu and approached to Kyoto again in 1336, Masashige suggested to Emperor Godaigo abandoning Yoshisada NITTA to make peace with Takauji, but the Emperor did not accept his suggestion, so Masashige advised him to take the second best way, that is, a temporary withdrawal from Kyoto, but it was also rejected.

When the Ashikaga's troops established themselves in Kyushu and approached Kyoto again in 1336, Masashige suggested to Emperor Godaigo abandoning Yoshisada NITTA to make peace with Takauji, but the Emperor did not accept his suggestion, so Masashige advised him to take the second best way, that is, a temporary withdrawal from Kyoto, but it was also rejected.

When the Ashikaga's troops established themselves in Kyushu and approached Kyoto again in 1336, Masashige suggested to Emperor Godaigo that the emperor should abandon Yoshisada NITTA to make peace with Takauji, but the Emperor did not accept his opinion, then Masashige advised him to take the second best policy, that is, a temporary withdrawal from Kyoto, which was also rejected.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 絶望的な状況下で義貞の麾下での出陣を命じられ、湊川の戦い（兵庫県神戸市）で足利直義の軍と戦い敗れて、弟の楠木正季と刺し違えたとされる。
sen.e: As he was ordered to depart for the front under Yoshisada's command in hopeless circumstances, he fought against the army of Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA in the Battle of Minatogawa (present-day Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture) to be defeated, so he and his younger brother Masasue KUSUNOKI are said to have stabbed each other.

He was ordered to depart for the front under Yoshisada's command due to the hopeless circumstance, he fought against the army of Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA in the Battle of Minatogawa (present-day Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture) to be defeated, so he and his younger brother Masasue KUSUNOKI are said to have stabbed each other.

He was ordered to depart for the front under Yoshisada's command due to the hopeless circumstance, he fought against the army of Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA in the Battle of Minatogawa (present-day Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture) to be defeated, so he is said to have stabbed each other with his younger brother Masasue KUSUNOKI.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 法名は霊光寺大圓義龍卍堂。
sen.e: His homyo (a Buddhist name given to a person who has died or has entered the priesthood) is Reikojidaiengiryumanjido.
sen.cmt: 霊光寺大圓義龍卍堂: 読み方が不明ですので、最も一般的と思われる読み方をローマ字で表記しております。「Reikojidaiingiryumanjido(読み方不明)」と登録されていますが、「圓」は「えん」ですので、そのように訂正しております。
sen.e: His homyo (a Buddhist name given to a person who has died or has entered the priesthood) is Reikojidaiengiryumanjido.
His posthumous buddhist name is Reikojidaiengiryumanjido.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 正成の息子である小楠公こと楠木正行を筆頭に、楠木正時、楠木正儀らも正成と同じく南朝方について戦った。
sen.e: Not only Masashige's son, Masatsura KUSUNOKI, also known as Sho-Nanko (the Younger Lord of Kusunoki), but also Masatoki KUSUNOKI, Masanori KUSUNOKI and others took the side of the Southern Court as well as Masashige to fight against the enemy.
sen.cmt: 小楠公: 用語登録では「Shonanko」とされていますが、「Dai-Nanko」の表記との整合性と、他に「楠公(Nanko)」という単語も出てくることから、「Sho-Nanko」の表記のほうが分かりやすいと思われるため、「Sho-Nanko」と表記しています。また、Guidelinesの指示による説明をカッコ内に入れていますが、これは定訳ではありません。
sen.e: Not only Masashige's son, Masatsura KUSUNOKI, also known as Sho-Nanko (the Younger Lord of Kusunoki), but also Masatoki KUSUNOKI, Masanori KUSUNOKI and others took the side of the Southern Court as well as Masashige to fight against the enemy.

Not only Masashige's son, Masatsura KUSUNOKI, also known as the Younger Lord of Kusunoki 'Sho-Nanko', but also Masatoki KUSUNOKI and Masanori KUSUNOKI took the side of the Southern Court as well as Masashige to fight against the enemy.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 正成の妻・久子は、夫・正成、長男・正行らの死後、戦乱の中、河内（甘南備村）を離れ、美濃国伊自良村長滝釜ヶ谷奥の院に隠棲。
sen.e: In the period of war Masashige's wife, Hisako, left Kawachi (Kannabi Village) after death of her husband Masashige, her eldest son Masatsura and other family members to live in seclusion in Okunoin, Nagataki kamagatani, Ijira-mura, Mino Province.

During the warring period, Masashige's wife, Hisako, left Kawachi (Kannabi Village) after death of her husband Masashige, her eldest son Masatsura and other family members to live in seclusion in Okunoin, Nagataki kamagatani, Ijira-mura, Mino Province.

During the warring period, Masashige's wife, Hisako, left Kawachi (Kannabi Village) after the death of her husband Masashige, her eldest son Masatsura and other family members to live in seclusion in Okunoin, Nagataki kamagatani, Ijira-mura, Mino Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 奥の院には、それを祀る甘南備神社がある。
sen.e: There is Kannabi-jinja Shrine deifying the clan at Okunoin.
sen.cmt: 「それ」が何を指すのか特定不能です(Webの原文通りなので、用語抜け等ではありません)。文脈からは、前文の「久子」を指すと思われますが、人物に「それ」という単語を用いるのは不自然であり、また、125列目に「久子は戦後、湊川神社に合祀された」との記述があり、甘南備神社に祀られているのは久子ではないと判断されるため、「一族(楠木家)」の意味で訳してあります。ただし、117列目に、この神社には「楠木家の遠祖と称える橘諸兄の父、美努王（みぬのおおきみ）」が祀られているという記述があるため、この文自体が不正確だと判断されます。
sen.e: There is Kannabi-jinja Shrine deifying the clan at Okunoin.
Kannabi-jinja Shrine deifying the clan is at Okunoin.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 地域の尊信を得て、河内乃国甘南備の字名、長滝、平井、掛、松尾等々を与える。
sen.e: After Hisako had gained the trust of the people in the area, she named some places there after the place names such as Nagataki, Hirai, Kake or Matsuo in Kannabi in Kawachi Province.
After Hisako had gained the trust of the people in the area, she named some places there after place names such as Nagataki, Hirai, Kake or Matsuo in Kannabi in Kawachi Province.
After Hisako had gained the trust of the people in the area, she named the places after Nagataki, Hirai, Kake, Matsuo and so force in Kannabi in Kawachi Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: その墓は伊自良湖の登り口、長滝七社神社境内横にある。
sen.e: Her grave is adjacent to the precincts of Nagataki Nana-sha-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 長滝七社神社: 用語登録では「Nagataki Nana-sha Shrine」となっていますが、仕様指示書によれば「Nagataki Nana-sha-jinja Shrine」とすべきですので、仕様指示書に合わせております。
sen.e: Her grave is adjacent to the precincts of Nagataki Nana-sha-jinja Shrine.
Her grave is adjacent to the precincts of Nagataki Nana-sha-jinja Shrine, at the foot of Ijira-ko Lake.
sen.cmt: at the foot of Ijira-ko Lake補足

tit.e: Evaluation of Masashige by later generations and his influence
Evaluation of Masashige by later generations and his influence
Evaluation of Masashige by later generations and his influence

sen.j: 南朝寄りの古典『太平記』では正成の事跡は強調して書かれているが、足利氏寄りの史書である『梅松論』でさえも同情的な書き方をされている。
sen.e: The achievements of Masashige were described with emphasis in the pro-Southern-Court classic "Taiheiki", but even in the pro-Ashikaga history book "Baishoron" (Historical tale compiled in 1349) he was described with some sympathy.

The achievements of Masashige were described with emphasis in the pro-Southern-Court classic "Taiheiki", but even in the pro-Ashikaga history book "Baishoron" (Historical tale compiled in 1349) he was described with some sympathy.

The achievements of Masashige were emphasized in the description contained in the pro-Southern-Court classic "Taiheiki," but in the pro-Ashikaga history book "Baishoron" (Historical tale compiled in 1349) he was described sympathetically.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 理由は、戦死した正成の首（頭部）を尊氏が「むなしくなっても家族はさぞや会いたかろう」と丁寧に遺族へ返還しているなど、尊氏自身が清廉な彼に一目置いていたためであろう。
sen.e: The reason was that Takauji acknowledged his clean personality and handed back the head of the fallen Masashige to his family in a polite way, saying that they must want to see him, although they might feel hollowed out.

The reason was that Takauji acknowledged his clean personality and handed back the head of the fallen Masashige to his family in a polite way, saying that they must want to see him, although they might feel hollowed out.

The reason was that Takauji acknowledged Masashige's integrity and handed back the head of the fallen Masashige to his family in a polite way, saying that they must want to see him, although they might feel sad.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 今日でいうゲリラ戦的戦法を得意とした正成の戦法は、江戸時代に楠木流の軍学として流行し、正成の末裔と称した楠木正辰（楠木不伝）の弟子だった由井正雪も南木流軍学を講じていた。
sen.e: As his tactics that excelled at present-day guerrilla warfare became prevalent as military science of Kusunoki-ryu style in the Edo period, Shosetsu YUI, a disciple of Masatatsu KUSUNOKI (Fuden KUSUNOKI), who claimed descent from Masashige, also taught the military science of Nagi-ryu style (military science proposed by Masatatsu KUSUNOKI).
sen.cmt: 「楠木流」: 定訳が不明ですので、登録されている「南木流」の訳語に合わせ、「Kusunoki-ryu style」と訳しております)。/ 南木流: 用語登録には「Nagi-ryu style」とだけ記載されていますが、説明が必要なため、カッコ内に説明を補足しています(この説明は定訳ではありません)。
sen.e: As his tactics that excelled at present-day guerrilla warfare became prevalent as military science of Kusunoki-ryu style in the Edo period, Shosetsu YUI, a disciple of Masatatsu KUSUNOKI (Fuden KUSUNOKI), who claimed descent from Masashige, also taught the military science of Nagi-ryu style (military science proposed by Masatatsu KUSUNOKI).

As his tactics that excelled at present-day guerrilla warfare became prevalent as military science of Kusunoki-ryu style in the Edo period, Shosetsu YUI, a disciple of Masatatsu KUSUNOKI (Fuden KUSUNOKI), who claimed descent from Masashige, also taught the military science of Nagi-ryu style.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 佩刀であったと伝承される小竜景光（東京国立博物館蔵）は、山田浅右衛門の手を経て、明治天皇の佩刀となった。
sen.e: Koryu Kagemitsu, a sword made by a sword craftsman Kagemitsu, which had been handed on to later generations as his carrying sword (a property of Tokyo National Museum), passed into the possession of Emperor Meiji as his carrying sword through Asaemon YAMADA.
sen.cmt: 小竜景光: 用語登録では「Kagemitsu KORYU」となっていますが、これは人名ではなく、刀の名称ですので、「Koryu Kagemitsu」と表記しています。その後の説明(a sword made by…)は定訳ではありません。
sen.e: Koryu Kagemitsu, a sword made by a sword craftsman Kagemitsu, which had been handed on to later generations as his carrying sword (a property of Tokyo National Museum), passed into the possession of Emperor Meiji as his carrying sword through Asaemon YAMADA.

Koryu Kagemitsu, a sword made by a sword craftsman Kagemitsu, which had been handed on to later generations as his carrying sword (a property of Tokyo National Museum), passed into the possession of Emperor Meiji as his carrying sword through Asaemon YAMADA.

sen.j: 明治天皇は大本営が広島に移った時も携えていたとされる。
sen.e: Emperor Meiji is said to have carried the sword, even when the Imperial headquarters were relocated to Hiroshima.
Emperor Meiji is said to have carried the sword, even when the Imperial headquarters were relocated to Hiroshima.
Emperor Meiji is said to have carried the sword, even when the Imperial headquarters were relocated to Hiroshima.

sen.j: また、明治政府は南朝功臣の子孫にも爵位を授けるため、正成の子孫を探したが、楠木氏末裔を自称する氏族は数多く全国各地に存在したが、学術的根拠の認められる直系子孫は国家権力を以てしても確認することが出来なかった。
sen.e: The Meiji Government looked for descendants of Masashige to confer descendants of the meritorious retainer of the Southern Court the dignity of a peerage, but it was not possible even for the state power to identify his direct descendants based on scientific evidence, although many clans throughout the nation claimed descent from the Kusunoki clan.
sen.cmt: 南朝功臣: 「meritorious retainer of Southern Dynasty」と登録されていますが、用語統一リストの南北朝に関する指示に合わせ、左記のように修正しております。
sen.e: The Meiji Government looked for descendants of Masashige to confer descendants of the meritorious retainer of the Southern Court the dignity of a peerage, but it was not possible even for the state power to identify his direct descendants based on scientific evidence, although many clans throughout the nation claimed descent from the Kusunoki clan.

The Meiji Government looked for descendants of Masashige to confer descendants of the meritorious retainer of the Southern Court the dignity of a peerage, but it was not possible even for the state power to identify his direct descendants based on scientific evidence, although many clans throughout the nation claimed descent from the Kusunoki clan.

sen.j: このため、新田氏、菊池氏、名和氏の子孫等は男爵に叙せられたが、楠木氏からは華族に加えられなかった。
sen.e: For this reason none of the Kusunoki clan was raised to the peerage, while descendants of the Nitta, Kikuchi and Nawa clans were baronized.
For this reason none of the Kusunoki clan was raised to the peerage, while descendants of the Nitta, Kikuchi and Nawa clans were baronized.
For this reason none of the Kusunoki clan were raised to the peerage, while descendants of the Nitta, Kikuchi and Nawa clans were baronized.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、大楠公600年祭（昭和10年）時には学術的根拠ある楠木氏の子孫が確認され、湊川神社内に楠木同族会が組織されて現在に至っている。
sen.e: But descendants of the Kusunoki clan were identified based on scientific evidence at the Dai-Nanko 600 years anniversary in 1935, so the Kusunoki family council has been organized at Minatogawa-jinja Shrine and continues to exist to this day.

But descendants of the Kusunoki clan were identified based on scientific evidence at the Dai-Nanko 600 years anniversary in 1935, so the Kusunoki family council has been organized at Minatogawa-jinja Shrine and continues to exist to this day.

But descendants of the Kusunoki clan were identified based on scientific evidence at the Dai-Nanko 600th anniversary in 1935, so the Kusunoki family council has been organized at Minatogawa-jinja Shrine and continues to exist.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 永禄2年（1559年）、正成の子孫と称した楠木正虎が献金により朝敵の赦免を嘆願し、正親町天皇の勅免を受けて朝敵でなくなる。
sen.e: Because Masatora KUSUNOKI, who claimed descent from Masashige, petitioned with a donation to pardon Masashige for the specification as an enemy of the court, he was pardoned by order of Emperor Ogimachi to be released from the specification.
sen.cmt: 勅免(勅命による赦免): 定訳が不明ですので、「be pardoned by order of ～」と訳しております。
sen.e: Because Masatora KUSUNOKI, who claimed to be a descendent of Masashige, petitioned with a donation to pardon Masashige for the specification as an enemy of the court, he was pardoned by order of Emperor Ogimachi to be released from the specification.

Because Masatora KUSUNOKI, who claimed to be a descendent of Masashige, petitioned through a donation that Masashige be pardoned from being named an enemy of the court, he was pardoned by order of Emperor Ogimachi in 1559.

sen.j: また江戸時代には水戸学の尊王思想の史家によって、忠臣として見直された。
sen.e: In the Edo period he was revaluated as a loyal subject by imperialistic historians of Mitogaku (the scholarship and academic traditions that arose in the Mito Domain).
sen.cmt: 尊王思想の史家: 定訳が不明ですので、「imperialistic historian」と訳しております。
sen.e: In the Edo period he was revaluated as a loyal subject by imperialistic historians of Mitogaku (the scholarship and academic traditions that arose in the Mito Domain).
In the Edo period he was revaluated as a loyal subject by imperialistic historians of Mitogaku.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代後期には尊皇家によって頻繁に祭祀されるようになり、その動きはやがてのちの湊川神社の創建に結実し、他方で靖国神社などの招魂社成立に大きな影響を与えることとなる。
sen.e: In the latter half of Edo period he was often enshrined by advocates of reverence for the Emperor, which led to the foundation of Minatogawa-jinja Shrine, and on the other hand it made a major impact on foundation of Shokon-sha Shrine such as Yasukuni-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 尊皇家: 定訳が不明ですので「advocate of reverence for the Emperor」(文中では複数形)と訳しております。
sen.e: In the latter half of Edo period he was often enshrined by advocates of reverence for the Emperor, which led to the foundation of Minatogawa-jinja Shrine, and on the other hand it made a major impact on foundation of Shokon-sha Shrine such as Yasukuni-jinja Shrine.

In the latter half of the Edo period he was often enshrined by advocates of reverence for the Emperor, which led to the foundation of Minatogawa-jinja Shrine, and also, it made a major impact on foundation of Shokon-sha Shrine such as Yasukuni-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 明治になり南北朝正閏論を経て南朝が正統であるとされると大楠公と呼ばれ、講談などでは『三国志演義』の諸葛亮の天才軍師的イメージを重ねて語られる。
sen.e: After the Southern Court had been legitimated through the Nanbokucho-Seijunron (argument on legitimacy of either Northern or Southern Court) in the Meiji period, he was called Dai-Nanko and was described in kodan storytelling and others as a person with a similar image of a genius strategist Zhuge Liang of "Romance of the Three Kingdoms".
sen.cmt: 南北朝正閏論: 「Nanbokucho-Seijunron (argument on legitimacy of either Northern or Southern Dynasty)」が登録されていますが、用語統一リストの指示に合わせて、左記のように修正しております。
sen.e: After the Southern Court had been legitimated through the Nanbokucho-Seijunron (argument on legitimacy of either Northern or Southern Court) in the Meiji period, he was called Dai-Nanko and was described in kodan storytelling and others as a person with a similar image of a genius strategist Zhuge Liang of "Romance of the Three Kingdoms".

After the Southern Court had been legitimatized through the argument on legitimacy of either Northern or Southern Court in the Meiji period, he was called Dai-Nanko and was compared in 'kodan' storytelling and other sources to the genius strategist Zhuge Liang of "Romance of the Three Kingdoms."
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また、皇国史観の下、戦死を覚悟で大義の為に逍遥と戦場に赴く姿が「忠臣の鑑」、「日本人の鑑」として讃えられ、修身教育でも祀られる。
sen.e: In Kokoku Shikan (emperor-centered historiography which is based on state Shinto) he was praised as "an exemplary loyal subject" or "a true Japanese" who went off to war with a heavy gait, being prepared to die for his cause, so that he was worshiped also in Shushin education (moral training education).
sen.cmt: 「逍遥」は「気ままにぶらぶら歩くこと」を意味しますが、ここでは文脈と合わないため、真意が不明です。絶望的な状況なのに戦場に行かざるを得ないため、「目標に向かって急ぐのではなく、重い足取りで(進む)」という意味と推測し、「with a heavy gait」としました。ただし、「自分の気持ちを押し殺して」と解釈すれば、「holding back his true feelings」等の挿入句が考えられます(個人的には後者が良いと思いますが、「新たな情報の追加」に当たる可能性があるため、表記しておりません)
sen.e: In Kokoku Shikan (emperor-centered historiography which is based on state Shinto) he was praised as "an exemplary loyal subject" or "a true Japanese" who went off to war with a heavy gait, being prepared to die for his cause, so that he was worshiped also in Shushin education (moral training education).

In the emperor-centered historiography which is based on state Shinto, he was praised as 'an exemplary loyal subject' or 'a true Japanese' who went off to war with a heavy gait, being prepared to die for his cause, so that he was worshiped also in the moral training education.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 戦後は価値観の転換と歴史学における中世史の研究が進むと悪党としての性格が強調されるようになり、吉川英治は『私本太平記』の中で戦前までのイメージとは異なる正成像を描いている。
sen.e: As values were changed and the study of medieval history in the historical science progressed after the war, his character as an Akuto was emphasized, so that Eiji YOSHIKAWA drew a different image of Masashige from that of prewar times in his book "Shihon Taihei ki" (A Private Book of War History).

As values were changed and the study of medieval history in the historical science progressed after the war, his character as an Akuto was emphasized, so that Eiji YOSHIKAWA drew a different image of Masashige from that of prewar times in his book "Shihon Taihei ki" (A Private Book of War History).

As values were changed and the study of medieval history in a historical science progressed after the war, his character as a rebel was emphasized, such that Eiji YOSHIKAWA drew a different image of Masashige from that of prewar times in his book "Shihon Taihei ki".
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.cmt: 八王寺宮: 登録された用語通りに表記していますが、「墓には『…Shrine(神社)』と刻まれている」という英文は、奇妙に響くのではないかと思われます(この場合は、この後のカッコに説明を入れていますので、「Shrine」を削除し、「Hachioji-gu」としたほうが良いかと存じます)。また、この名称の意味は不明ですが、カッコ内に漢字の説明を入れています(これは定訳ではありません。また、「宮」は「神社」のほかに「宮殿」等の意味もあるので、カッコ内に補足しています)。 / 楠公: 英文では、この用語が「大楠公」と同じ意味で用いられていることが分からないため、カッコ内に説明として「楠木正成」の名を入れています。

sen.j: 楠公夫人がこの地に訪れた最大の理由は、新田義貞亡き後、その弟の脇屋義助が大将となり、北陸で破れ、美濃の南朝一派と共に、最後の根尾城の戦いでも破れ、根尾川の下流、本巣地区の北朝の根城を避け、一緒に戦った伊自良次郎左衛門の家臣と共に、伊自良に流れ、吉野に帰ったその経路に従ったものと思われる。
sen.e: The main reason for her visit there appears that she followed the track of Yoshisuke WAKIYA, who was a younger brother of Yoshisada NITTA, became a commander after death of his brother, was defeated in Hokuriku region, lost also the last battle, i. e., the Battle of Neo-jo Castle, with a pro-Southern-Court group of Mino, avoided the headquarters of the Northern Court in Motosu District in lower reach of Neo-gawa River, fled to Ijira with the vassals of Jirozaemon IJIRA, who fought with him, and finally went back to Yoshino.

sen.j: 奉建塔（楠公六百年記念塔）
sen.e: Hoken-to Tower (Nanko 600 years anniversary tower)
Hoken-to Tower (Nanko 600 years anniversary tower)
Hoken-to Tower (Nanko 600th anniversary tower)
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 没後600年を記念して、昭和15年（1940年）に全国の児童学生や教職員等の募金により浄心寺塞（上赤坂城支塞）跡に建てられた記念塔。
sen.e: The tower was built in 1940 at the former site of the fort of Joshin-ji Temple (auxiliary fort of Kamiakasaka-jo Castle) by donations from pupils, students, teachers and others throughout the country to mark the 600th anniversary of his death.
sen.cmt: 支塞: 定義と定訳は確認できませんでしたが、「塞」は「とりで」を意味するので、ここでは「(「支」という漢字が示唆する意味の)副次的な、補助的なとりで、要塞」等を意味すると推測し、その意味で「auxiliary fort」と訳しています。
sen.e: The tower was built in 1940 at the former site of the fort of Joshin-ji Temple (auxiliary fort of Kamiakasaka-jo Castle) by donations from pupils, students, teachers and others throughout the country to mark the 600th anniversary of his death.

sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 正成討死の年齢43歳に因み、高さはおよそ43尺（約13ｍ）。
sen.e: The height of the tower was set at forty three shaku (approximately thirteen meters), because he died in battle at the age of forty three.
The height of the tower was set at forty three shaku (approximately thirteen meters), because he died in battle at the age of forty three.

sen.j: 塔には家紋の菊水紋、旗印の「非理法権天」の文字が刻まれている。
sen.e: The family crest, Kikusui-mon (pattern of floating flowers on a stream) and the characters of the emblem on flag "Hirihokenten" (literally Wrong, Right, Law, Power, Heaven) are engraved on the tower.

sen.j: 楠公産湯の井戸
sen.e: Nanko ubuyu no ido (water well for Nanko's first bath)

sen.j: 生誕の地から徒歩数分のところに「楠公産湯の井戸」とされる井戸がある。
sen.e: "Nanko ubuyu no ido", which is said to be a water well for Nanko's first bath, is a few minutes walk away from his birthplace.
